Comments_List: This course helped me develop insight into multivariable mathematics techniques. From introduction to 3D space to learning how to solve work and flux integrals, I have been able to develop a pretty comprehensive understanding.
further knowledge of calculus, now in the three dimensional space
I developed three-dimensional calculus skills, including work, vector line integrals, three-dimensional calculations.

I've learned how to do triple integrals and partial derivatives, how to find line integrals of scalar functions and vector fields, and how to apply green's theorem, stokes' theorem and divergence theorem.
I wish there were more summaries and help of all the concepts.

I think the course is taught in a very logical timeline. It first introduces the mechanics of the material and then turns back to applications of these mechanics. One weakness of the course is that it rushes through a bit of how some of the concepts overlap.

strengths: good foundation for multivariable calculus
weaknesses: seems like most students begin the course with some exposure or experience to the content, may be imbalanced for those who haven't had exposure yet

Strengths: the ximera's are extremely helpful (videos + practice problems you can use when you don't understand something / can't make it to class) 
Weaknesses: Differences across professors in how they teach and what's on the test, psets are too easy compared to the tests
Only if they are interested/required to take it.
I would absolutely recommend this course. It is filled with new, fun mathematics topics. As someone who was a bit discouraged after 115, Math 120 helped reignite my passion for math.
only if they need it for a prereq
Depends on what you are looking for. In retrospect, as an econ major, Math 118 would have been a better choice, but if you are looking into the field of engineering or physics yeah.
